lines.content: The DeleteModule functionality allows users to remove a module from the ModuleList.
It is facilitated by DeleteModuleCommand class which is an extension of the Command class.
Given below is an example usage scenario and how the delete mechanism behaves at each step.
When user executes the command `delmod cs2113` the Parser class calls the `DeleteModuleCommand()` method of the
The constructor of the DeleteModuleCommand class takes in a
moduleCode `cs2113` as a parameter. This moduleCode is
used to find `cs2113`  from the ModuleList.
The setUpLogger() method sets up the logger for the DeleteModuleCommand class. It creates a ConsoleHandler and a
The execute() method is overridden to execute the delete module functionality. It takes in the necessary parameters,
including the ModuleList, Ui, Storage, and TaskList.
Step 4: Find the module to delete :
The first step in the execute() method is to find the module using the module code parameter  `cs2113` by calling
the `findModule()` method of the moduleList class.
If the module `cs2113` is not found, a ModuleNotFoundException is thrown.
Step 5: Remove the module from the ModuleList :
If `cs2113` is found, it is removed from the ModuleList by calling `remove()` method of moduleList class.
A confirmation message is printed to the user indicating that the `cs2113` has been successfully deleted.
The storage is updated with the new ModuleList without `cs2113`
The target user profile is an average NUS student who:
* has a need to manage a significant number of tasks (todo, event, deadline) and modules,
* prefer desktop applications over other types of applications,
* is reasonably comfortable using CLI apps.
Existing schedulers do not have access to NUSâ€™s database, making it so that a student here would have to manually
input all their lessons. We can expedite this process by creating a scheduler that sets itself up via module codes.
It can also alert the user to possible event clashes.
| Priority | Version | As a ... | I want to ...             | So that I can ...                                           |
|          |  v1.0   | new user | see usage instructions    | refer to them when I forget how to use the application      |
|          |  v2.0   |   user   | find a to-do item by name | locate a to-do without having to go through the entire list |
* Should work on any mainstream OS as long as it has Java 11 or above installed.
* Should be able to hold up to 1000 tasks without a noticeable sluggishness in performance for typical usage.
* A user with above average typing speed for regular English text (i.e. not code, not system admin commands) should be
able to accomplish most of the tasks faster using commands than using the mouse.
## Appendix B: Instructions for manual testing
Given below are instructions to test the app manually.
> Note: These instructions only provide a starting point for testers to work on;
> testers are expected to do more *exploratory* testing.
Apollo is a timetable organiser written in java made for the average NUS students by NUS students!
Apollo works as a desktop app for managing your tasks, events, deadlines and modules optimized for use via a Command
**If you can type fast, Apollo can get your timetable management done faster than traditional GUI apps.**
### Integrate tasks and modules to make weekly schedule
* Add 3 different types of tasks : todos,deadlines,events
* Mark them as done or not done
* See the tasks + classes for the day
## How to install and run the project
1. Download the jar file from the releases below
2. Copy the jar file into an empty folder
3. Open a command window in that folder
Welcome to Apollo, a timetable organiser made for the average NUS students by NUS students!
Apollo is a desktop app for managing your tasks, events, deadlines and modules optimized for use via a Command Line
If you can type fast, Apollo can get your timetable management done faster than traditional GUI apps.
1. Ensure that you have Java `11` or above installed on your Personal Computer.
3. Copy the file to the folder you want to use as the home folder for your Apollo. This folder must be *empty*.
4. Open a command terminal, cd into the directory you put the jar file in and run the command `java -jar tp.jar`.
5. On opening, Apollo should greet you with this:
Enter "help" to see a list of commands.
> + Words in `UPPER_CASE` are the parameters to be supplied by the user.
> > e.g. in 'todo TASK', `TASK` is a parameter that can be used as `todo read book`.
> + The `date` command only considers tasks when `DATE` is input in the format `yyyy-MM-ddThh:mm`.
> > e.g. `deadline read book /by 2023-10-30T23:59` sets a deadline for Oct 20 2023, 11:59PM
> + By default, all newly added tasks are not completed.
Shows a menu of commands available in Apollo and their usage, as well as their required format/parameters.
Shows a numbered list of all tasks (Todos, Events, Deadlines) in Apollo.
You have a total of 4 tasks in your tasklist.
Here are the tasks in your list:
There are 4 unmarked tasks in your tasklist.
Adds a normal task to Apollo.
Got it. I've added this todo:
Adds a task with a due date to Apollo.
- Enter `DATE` in `yyyy-MM-ddThh:mm` format to use `date` on this task.
Got it. I've added this deadline:
Adds a task with a start and end date to Apollo.
- Enter `DATE` in `yyyy-MM-ddThh:mm` format to use `date` on this task.
Got it. I've added this event:
Marks the specified task as completed.
- `IDX` can be obtained by using `list` to find the task's index.
Nice!, I've marked this task as done:
Marks the specified task as not completed.
- `IDX` can be obtained by using `list` to find the task's index.
OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:
Deletes the specified task from Apollo.
- `IDX` can be obtained by using `list` to find the task's index.
Now you have 3 tasks in the list
Shows all tasks in Apollo that contain the specified keyword.
Here are the matching tasks in your list:
Shows all tasks in Apollo that occur on the specified date.
- `DATE` should be entered in the format `yyyy-MM-dd`.
Here are the tasks happening on Mar 30 2023:
> Note: `MODULE_CODE` can be either uppercase or lowercase. However, if the module code is not found in NUSMods,
> Apollo will not add the invalid module into the list.
Got it. I've added this module:
Total modular credits you have in this semester: 36
Here are the lesson types for this module:
To see how to add lessons, enter 'help'.
There are many lesson options and types, the below is a list of all the flags and their respective lesson types.
To add a lesson, use the following format:
This will add the first section teaching lesson of CS1010 to your module list.
- `IDX` can be obtained by using `list` to find the task's index.
Got it, removed CS2113 from your Module list.
Shows a list of all modules in Apollo.
You are taking 7 module(s) this semester:
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
Apollo automatically loads up your todo and module lists on start-up.
After any command that changes the data, Apollo will save the changes into your hard disk automatically.
The save file for your tasks is located at save.txt within the *home folder* for Apollo.
The save file for your modules is located at moduleData.txt within the *home folder* for Apollo.
If either file is corrupted, Apollo will show you a warning before the welcome message.
